intro: Anethum graveolens var. segetum, commonly known as cumin, is an annual herbaceous plant native to the Mediterranean region and parts of Asia. It produces small, spherical seeds that are widely used as a spice in various cuisines around the world. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with branched stems and feathery, aromatic leaves. Its flowers are small and yellow, arranged in umbels, and it thrives in well-drained soils with full sunlight. Cumin is cultivated for its seeds, which contain essential oils and are valued for their distinct flavor and medicinal properties.
